comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] New side chapel & sacristy (Blessed Thaddeus Chapel and sacristy built by John Sisk); completion of tower & spire (spire built by J. Maguire, Cork); carving to front by Harrison & Sons; further additions. Consecrated Aug 1919.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] It looks like the usual 4 digit number, though I can't make it out. This is one of Lawrence New Series, like the Skibbereen photo we had last Monday - a series where William Lawrence wasn't happy with the quality. He must have had very exacting standards! So, looks as if they scratched out the number on the original glass plate negative, and you can see N.S. (new series) 48 down the bottom now. Effectively the 48th of his rejects...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Aha! The Soldiers Home building was rebuilt in "AD 1900" according to this GoogleMapsStreetView - not the building here (see note). So definitely before 1900.

comment.author: 16693700@N03
comment._content: the small boats with the pointy bit at each end look like yawls or drontheims which are more usually seen in the North West. You can see a couple of chaps working on the sail of one on the dry near the centre of the picture.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: "DISASTROUS FIRE IN QUEENSTOWN: EXCITING SCENES" (reported Feb 3rd 1899) "completely demolishing the entire premises known as Soldiers' Home and Sailors' Rest as well as the business premises of Messrs Tyler, boot and shoe manufacturer" ... "three dozen pairs of boots and shoes saved" Warning: no lives lost but report does contain semi-nudity. So before Feb 1899

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16693700@N03] I would always have understood that a Yawl was a two masted sailing vessel but I find that the definition has expanded to include a ships Jolly boat or a boat rowed by four or six men (women probably don't count!)  Similar boats to those on the Shannon estuary where I hail from are known as Ganlows and supposedly based on the word Gondola???

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Advert in Freeman's June 16 1888. In 1898 it was advertised as being "To Let", with "large spirit bar and independent seven day licence", and Mrs Giumbini/Guimbini announced that she had opened the Ranville Hotel, Rutland Square, Dublin

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: They say that the Great Fire at Cobh Was due to a faulty gas stobh. Some ladies were viewed In the [*gasp*] semi-nude - Pure treasure for some sailor's trobh!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Hmmm. It may have had a large spirit bar etc in 1898, but in 1887 it was being advertised as the "Beach Temperance Hotel". with reduced terms from Oct 1st, and "specially recommended for Invalids for the winter"

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: A more detailed account of the fire from the Belfast News-letter. No nudity (semi or otherwise) in this one, but in describing the destroyed buildings it reports "much money has been spent on their erection in the last six years" which gives an earliest date for the photo of 1893. One family fled from an adjoining building, but forgot to take their baby boy with them. D'oh!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The movable boudoir was at Chancellor and Son's, just round the corner from the Gunpowder Office Chancellor's building also features prominently on the cover of the score of The Fireman's Polka The subject of chalets de nécessité (or that particular circumlocution) first occurred in connection with this picture.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16693700@N03] A yawl is any boat with a "pointy" stern double ender is the local term in my neck of the woods. Ref NLI photo, farm8.staticflickr.com/7053/6961206321_b11b83dcde_s.jpg. It is very interesting that teh sails are the same as used in Achill (dipping lug) One thoery up my way is that locals copied yawls used by Cromwells soldiers. Drontheims are a scandanavian Yawl also to be found in Donegal. The drontheim is named after a town in Sweden I believe.
